message: Wishing everyone across eastern Connecticut a safe and Happy New Year!

It has been a remarkable 24 hours for the House GOP and the new Congress that starts today. After voting in the dead of night and behind closed doors to eviscerate the independent office that reviews ethics complaints against members of Congress, the Republican majority today caved to overwhelming public pressure and reversed themselves. It is hard to conceive how such a foolish proposal could have been passed as their first action of the new Congress. I hope they have received the message loud and clear that the American people will be watching every move they make from here on out.

I continue to hear from many constituents impacted by crumbling foundations. A report was released yesterday by the Department of Consumer Protection detailing the efforts of Commissioner Jonathan Harris and his team to solve this horrific problem. One thing that is clear: this is going to require a concerted effort from all levels of government in order to develop tangible solutions for impacted homeowners.   Crumbling foundations have so far impacted 23 Connecticut communities. The damage to homes has the potential to harm the local housing market and could ripple across our state, hindering our efforts to achieve a full economic recovery. My office received confirmation last August that federal resources can be applied to this problem through the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Local leaders are hard at work trying to leverage these resources, which combined with help from other stakeholders, insurers, lenders and home builders can stop the escalating harm this report identifies. I look forward to working with along with them and my colleagues in the federal delegation to further flush out such opportunities for relief.

The Navy announced yesterday that the Columbia-class submarine program passed ”‘Milestone B” in the defense acquisition process, an important technical step. Now the process of steel-cutting and welding can begin for this next-generation program that will bring thousands of jobs to our region for decades to come.

In February of 2010, a horrifying natural gas explosion at the Kleen Energy Systems Plant in Middletown killed six workers, including my dear friend Ron Crabb, and injured dozens more. It was later determined that the blast was caused by the unsafe but legal practice known as “blow-downs,” in which workers use natural gas to clean pipes.  As we approach the seventh anniversary of this tragedy, it is clearer than ever that workplace safety regulations can save lives – which is why I spoke on the floor yesterday to oppose a bill that would add more red tape to the regulatory process, and make it even harder for OSHA and other agencies to protect American workers.

I had the honor of joining VFW Post No. 5095 and residents from East Hampton on Saturday for a Yellow Ribbon ceremony to show support for U.S. Navy Commander Michael Flatley and his wife and children. Commander Flatley will be deploying overseas for the fourth time. Despite a raging snowstorm oustide the post, there was standing room only turnout of area veterans, neighbors, and town officials to show support for the Commander. As always, the Patriot Riders were in attendance.  During the ceremony, Commander Flatley and his wife hung a yellow ribbon on a tree to honor him during his deployment. We wish the Commander a safe deployment and a speedy return home to his friends and family.

Great news from Electric Boat President Jeff Geiger that the company plans to make 1,350 new hires in Connecticut this year alone! And that number doesn’t even include the jobs that will be created across the network of nearly 500 small parts suppliers and precision manufacturing firms that support work at the shipyard. The growth at EB is continuing to drive a robust economic recovery across our region, and I promise to continue to support our undersea fleet and submarine construction at EB in my role as the ranking member of the Seapower subcommittee in Washington.

Check out this piece from WTNH about the “manufacturing pipeline” workforce education program, which is changing lives by training local residents to fill high-skilled, high-paying jobs across our region. I was proud to support this program by helping to obtain a $6 million dollar grant from the Department of Labor. Formerly unemployed or underemployed workers are now able to train for skilled labor positions at Electric Boat and other manufacturers on the EB supply chain, receive health and childcare benefits, and build a future for their loved ones.

Today, I spoke on the House floor to share just a small sample of calls and emails I’ve received from people in eastern Connecticut who are concerned about what repealing the Affordable Care Act without a replacement will mean for them. Let’s be clear: the Affordable Care Act is working for tens of millions of families. It is beyond reckless for Congressional Republicans to repeal people’s health insurance without having any plan to replace it. #ACAWorks #StopACARepeal
On this Martin Luther King Jr. Day, one line stands out as particularly relevant for this moment: "Of all the forms of inequality, injustice in health care is the most shocking and inhumane."

Thanks to all of the amazing supporters from across Connecticut who turned up in Hartford on Sunday to show support for health coverage and preserving the Affordable Care Act. I have heard from many residents and small business owners in eastern Connecticut who receive health insurance through the #ACA and are terrified that Republicans in Congress are going to repeal their coverage. Let’s be clear: the ACA works for tens of millions of families across the US and there is no alternative being proposed which can equal its success. Let’s stop this reckless assault on health insurance before it goes any further! #ACAWorks #StopACARepeal

I joined state and local officials in Preston yesterday to make public the long-awaited plan for redeveloping the closed Norwich Hospital site. The Town of Preston is on track to host a brand new multimillion dollar complex that will create hundreds of local jobs. Preston’s decision to partner with the Mohegan Tribe, whose roots in the area goes back centuries, is an enduring commitment that no other developer can match. I am proud that my office worked so closely with town officials to obtain federal brownfields grant funding from the EPA in 2012 and 2014 to help pay for the environmental cleanup that was necessary to get us to this point.

Last year my office was able to help save or return $2.2 million dollars directly to eastern Connecticut residents by conducting constituent casework in our Norwich and Enfield offices. Constituent casework is when members of my staff provide assistance to local residents who are struggling to cut through red tape in order to resolve an issue with the federal government. These issues can include clearing up disputes with the IRS, complications with receiving Social Security or veterans’ benefits or helping families to secure mortgage modifications. If you or anyone you know is having a difficult time resolving an issue with the federal government, please have them contact my Norwich or Enfield office for assistance. You can find the contact information on my website: www.courtney.house.gov
After attending yesterday's peaceful transition of power, today I am on the Mall to peacefully support #EqualRights

Last week, I shared new data from Medicare that demonstrates how the Affordable Care Act (ACA), or Obamacare, saved senior citizens in my district nearly $20 million dollars on prescription drugs in 2016. When the ACA was passed in 2010, it contained provisions to close the so-called ‘donut hole’ in Medicare Part D coverage which otherwise would have made the program less effective at lowering the cost of prescription drugs. Last year, the 14,531 seniors in eastern Connecticut who participated in the Part D prescription drug program saved an average of $1,808.00 per beneficiary – for a total savings of $19.8 million. And these savings for seniors are expected to continue to grow each year until the Part D donut hole is completely phased out in 2020 – that is as long as the relevant ACA provisions are not repealed by Congressional Republicans and the new President. #ACAworks #stopACArepeal

Yesterday, I spoke on the House floor to make it clear that I am shocked that one of President Trump’s first actions in office was to roll back a scheduled rate decrease on mortgage insurance for first-time homebuyers. One of the last things the outgoing Obama Administration did was to reduce the annual fee on insurance for FHA home loans from .85 percent to .6 percent – saving the average family about $500 per year. Within an hour of his inauguration, the new President signed an executive order to cancel this rate decrease – without any conceivable justification because the money that FHA makes on this fee is pure profit for the government. I have heard from a bipartisan chorus of realtors and homebuilders who are dumbfounded by this move. Not a great start if his mission is to stand up for middle-class and working families.

The planned multimillion-dollar condo complex near Fort Trumbull featured in The Day this morning is more evidence that new jobs being created at Electric Boat and its suppliers are driving an economic resurgence across our region. EB hired nearly 1,500 new workers last year and expects to hire another 1,300 this year! This is drawing people to eastern Connecticut and providing a major boost for our real estate market.

I stood with local healthcare providers and community members in Norwich yesterday to oppose the reckless repeal which the Republican majority rammed through Congress on January 13th - without the faintest hint of a replacement law. I walked through the Congressional Budget Office analysis which shows that a repeal of the law will put the health coverage of 30 million Americans at risk. Well over 130 people from across Eastern CT joined me to express their outrage at the rush to dismantle patient protections such as elimination of the preexisting conditions exclusion, ban on lifetime limits, exchange subsidies, and Medicaid expansion.   These protections have driven Eastern CT’s uninsured rate down from 6.9% to 3.6% - its lowest level ever. I read aloud from emails sent to my office from self-employed individuals such as a local farmer, nurses, and others who obtained affordable coverage for the first time in years through the ACA. With the budget reconciliation process coming to a head in late February or early March, it is a critical time for the public to speak out and call Congress to stop reckless legislation that will strip patients and families of access to quality care.

It has become painfully clear over the past several days that when President Trump ordered a blanket hiring freeze across the entire federal government, he and his staff did not consider the collateral damage such an action would cause – particularly for our veterans. While the White House exempted military personnel, they simply neglected to make any exemption for support personnel, or for the Department of Veterans affairs which needs to hire civilian medical staff. It is incredibly damaging to interrupt the normal hiring process because such actions cannot be easily undone. I joined a number of my colleagues yesterday in sending a letter to President Trump asking that he immediately reverse the order as it relates to the VA. I would also encourage the new President to learn more about the important work that our dedicated civil service employees carry out across the country every day.

President Trump’s new executive order freezing refugee arrivals and visa requests from a number of predominately Muslim countries will boomerang against us both morally and practically. The new President signed the order on Holocaust Remembrance Day, a day when we reflect in part on how our country failed to protect Jewish refugees from Nazi atrocities during World War II. This is not who we are as Americans: we do not discriminate against any religion, and we do not shut our doors to suffering people seeking a better life.

I will join House And Senate colleagues tomorrow evening at the Supreme Court to stand with refugees, immigrants, and others to call on President Trump to reverse his blatantly unconstitutional and un-American executive orders.   As we know today, many national security leaders such as former Defense Secretary Robert Gates, who served under eight Presidents, said this order is a betrayal of Iraqis who assisted US military and sends a very dangerous message to our allies in the Middle East.

Moments ago, I spoke up to condemn President’s Trump’s executive orders which will prohibit the brave Iraqis who are assisting coalition military forces fighting ISIL from traveling or immigrating to the United States. Since 2008, there has been strong bipartisan support for allowing Iraqi translators and others who help our military to immigrate to America under special immigrant visas. Trump’s haphazard and reckless orders have slammed the door shut on our partners in the fight against ISIL – removing one of the strongest incentives for locals to join us in the fight against terrorism.

I am sharing an important story from The Day which explains how one international student attending Connecticut College in New London is facing extreme uncertainty due to President Trump’s reckless immigration orders. The piece features Ibrahim Mohamed, a 21-year-old freshman from Somalia, here lawfully on a student visa, who is unsure if he will be allowed to return to the U.S. if he travels home for summer break.   Under President Trump’s executive order, Somalia is one of the seven countries whose citizens are barred from traveling into the U.S., even a student like Ibrahim who has a valid student visa. The international student programs that are offered at eastern Connecticut colleges such as Conn College, UConn, and ECSU have a very important mission, not just for the individual students who benefit from attending our great schools, but also for the long-term benefit of fostering understanding and friendships that the students will take back to their native countries for the rest of their lives. It is “grass roots diplomacy” at its best, and it strengthens our nation’s standing in the world. These students will help to dispel the negative narratives that enemies of democracy and freedom try to disseminate about our country and our way of life. The travel ban announced last Friday cripples that effort and as Senator John McCain aptly said, it is a “self-inflicted wound.”

Last weekend, I had the chance to hear directly from my constituents impacted by crumbling foundations at a town hall meeting in Vernon, and speak with the Real Story on Fox 61 about a few recent developments on the issue. Specifically, the State of Connecticut will move to utilize $1 million in federal grant funding from HUD which I determined was available for communities with crumbling foundation last August. Crumbling foundations have impacted dozens of communities across central and northeastern Connecticut, and while this funding is significant, it will not be enough on its own to solve this terrible problem. I promise to continue working with both the state and federal government to determine what other resources or funding may be available to assist homeowners struggling with crumbling foundations.

I hope you caught my op-ed in The Day this past weekend on how increasing work at Electric Boat its suppliers is driving the economic recovery and boosting the housing market in eastern Connecticut. The company expects to hire nearly 1,300 new workers this year alone, and nearly 14,000 over the next 15 years. Even towns far from the shoreline are feeling the impact of the new work because the shipyard is supported by nearly 500 other parts suppliers across our state.   A specific issue I discuss is the challenge of workforce training to fill such a large number of new highly-skilled potions. It’s going to take a coordinated effort to get enough new employees trained to fill these positions at EB and its suppliers and we are already off to a great start with the eastern CT manufacturing pipeline operating at community colleges across our region. We need to continue to build on the success of this program and ensure it remains funded well into the future.

As a member of the House Education & Workforce Committee, I spoke up during a hearing of the K-12 subcommittee this morning to defend the role that public education plays in our country, and make clear that privatizing schools and moving to a voucher system would not be an effective solution for reducing poverty, increasing diversity, or improving education. Just a few weeks ago for example, the Charles Barnham School, a public elementary school in Groton, received a National Blue Ribbon Award from the U.S. Department of Education for the spectacular math and reading scores its students achieved thanks to the incredible teamwork of its teachers, students administrators, and parents. The notion that public education is doomed is a false narrative.  There is no question about it: public education was one of the main drivers of our national success during the 20th century and is one of the reasons why America is ALREADY great. I will oppose any and all efforts to privatize education, or move resources away from our public schools. This is why I oppose the nomination Betsy DeVos—someone who profits from the privatization of education, and has no experience or respect for the important role that public schools play in educating our children.

I had a great meeting with the Australian Ambassador to the United States in my Washington office this morning. Australia has long been one of America’s closest allies on the global stage, and I reiterated to Ambassador Hockey that Congress and the American people stand with our Australian friends. I look forward to working with him to further strengthen the unshakable strategic, economic, and cultural bonds between our two countries.

Yesterday, I had the honor of joining the Enfield American Legion Post for their annual "Four Chaplains Mass." The service commemorates the 1943 sinking of the SS Dorchester, and to remember the sacrifice of four Army chaplains, forever known as the "Immortal Chaplains," who gave away their life jackets in order to save other sailors from drowning. The Enfield service is the longest running continuous observation of this tragic event in the country. Thanks to all of the local veterans who organize this tribute each winter.

I support the efforts of my Senate colleagues who are holding the floor against an unqualified nominee to lead the Department of Education. Betsy DeVos is facing unprecedented resistance from a bipartisan group of Republican, Democratic, and Independent Senators as her nomination has generated an avalanche of calls and emails into Washington expressing public opposition. During the confirmation hearing process, she has displayed a disturbing lack of command on fundamental issues such as special education and Title One. Her feckless disregard for basic notions of accountability for education spending was shocking.   As a longtime member of the House Education and Workforce Committee, I know that our public education system is one of the reasons America is ALREADY great.  Hopefully, the outpouring of opposition and determined efforts of Senators holding the floor will flip the one remaining vote our children need to stop this nomination.

This week I was once again selected as the ranking member of the Seapower and Projection Forces subcommittee, overseeing the Navy, Marine Corps, and some Air Force programs for the House Armed Services Committee. When I was designated as the ranking member in 2015, I became the first Connecticut member to serve in the leadership of a naval subcommittee in more than 40 years. In my role, I am able to support Connecticut’s industrial economy by advocating for increased work at Electric Boat and its network of suppliers. With the Navy planning a large shipbuilding expansion in the near future, I am glad that I will continue to have the opportunity to represent Connecticut’s interests every step of the way.

Tonight, a bipartisan panel of judges serving on the 9th Circuit stood up for the Constitution and defended our highest ideals when they unanimously ruled against President Donald Trump’s precipitous and misguided ban on refugees and immigrants from some Muslim countries.  The Court reaffirmed John Adams' timeless declaration that “we are a nation of laws, not of men."

While submarine production continues to ramp up at Electric Boat, I am leading the charge to ensure that we properly maintain the ships that are already in the fleet in order to maximize their service life while minimizing their time in the shipyard. Currently, the Navy is experiencing a serious maintenance backlog that is causing ships to be taken out of service for unacceptable lengths of time. I am strongly encouraging the Navy to utilize our private shipyards, like EB, to reduce the logjam at public Navy yards and get our ships redeployed.  In 2015-2016, my office coordinated with the Navy and EB to bring the USS Montpelier to Groton for repairs and that work is being successfully carried out today. As Ranking Member of the House Seapower Subcommittee, I will continue to build on this model of public-private partnership so we reduce the backlog and maintain the naval readiness which is so critical to our national security.

I was honored to stand with the 103rd Airlift Wing of the Connecticut Air National Guard during their sendoff ceremony on Saturday. We looked on as 300 airmen, known as ‘Flying Yankees’, prepared for deployment to the Middle East where they will join 100 members of their unit already serving abroad.  This deployment is the culmination of years of work by General Thad Martin and Colonel Frank Detorie to secure their new C-130H flying mission and the significant investments necessary to upgrade their base in Windsor Locks. I was proud to support their efforts as a member of the House Armed Services Committee at every step of the way. I wish them all the best during their deployment and look forward to their safe return to Connecticut.  Video courtesy of the Connecticut Air National Guard

I stood with hundreds of local residents in Mystic on Saturday in opposition to a proposed rail realignment which would cut new tracks straight through several historic shoreline communities. It is unacceptable that a plan to connect Washington, DC to Boston with high-speed tracks should come at the expense of long established communities that would be butchered by the new Federal Railroad Administration map. Please click this link if you would like to read more about my efforts to stop all funding for this project: http://bit.ly/2kmS9jg

The Russian spy ship patrolling 30 miles off the coast of Groton and the SUBASE underscores the very real threat posed by a resurgent Russia. This unacceptable, aggressive action, combined with the buzzing of US Navy ships in the Black Sea yesterday, is a clear indication that Russia is testing the resolve of the new Administration. I have total confidence in our Navy’s vigilant, responsible readiness, but the White House needs to move past their infatuation with Putin and treat him like the serious threat to global peace that he has been for the last five years.

Geno Auriemma and the UConn Huskies won their 100th consecutive game earlier this week. I spoke on the House floor to honor this remarkable and unprecedented achievement. Coach Auriemma’s program continues to be THE model of excellence on and off the court. These are true student-athletes, and even after 11 championships, the sky continues to be the limit for our Huskies. #BleedBlue

Today is a #NationalDayofAction to preserve and protect the Affordable Care Act, a law that has helped to provide health insurance to tens-of-millions of Americans for the first time. I hosted an event at the Generations Family Health Center in Willimantic where more than two-hundred people showed up to voice their concerns about what a repeal of the law could mean for local families. Sometimes people forget that many of the protections they now take for granted, like allowing young people to stay on their parent's plans until age 26, a ban against lifetime limits on coverage, protections for those with pre-existing conditions, and a prohibition against charging women more for coverage only exist because of the Affordable Care Act.   I am glad so many people turned out in eastern Connecticut and across the country today to show their support for this cornerstone of our modern healthcare system. They are telling President Trump and Congressional Republicans that we are not going back now: #stopACArepeal #ACAworks

The rash of threats against Jewish Community Centers and similar acts of anti-Semitism across the country are a disturbing development for the United States and represent a troubling step backward toward intolerance and hatred. We must move quickly as a society to condemn hateful and discriminatory actions against Jewish-Americans or any other group, and we must rise above these attempts to divide our country and our people from one another. Let’s use this as an opportunity to remind our children and our neighbors that diversity makes us stronger - not weaker - and the success of our country is built on bringing together people from all over the world, whether they are African-American, Irish, Italian, Jewish, Muslim, Mexican, or any other race or religion.

I will be holding a town hall meeting at Kelly Middle School in Norwich tomorrow night. I am looking forward to hearing from many of you about your priorities for the new Congress and providing you with an update on several issues I have been working on in Washington and across eastern Connecticut. The doors will open at 6:00 PM and the meeting will begin at 6:30. I hope to see you and your family tomorrow night!

Great turnout at our town hall meeting in Norwich last night with more than 250 local residents in attendance. I was happy to answer questions from several families concerned about a repeal of the Affordable Care Act and the future of public education, along with a host of other topics. Eastern Connecticut is clearly fired up and ready to fight for our New England values. Thanks to all who spent their Thursday night sharing their stories and concerns with me. I’m looking forward to taking your messages back to Washington
NA

PLEASE SHARE: On March 24, I will be hosting a Vietnam Veterans 50th Commemoration Ceremony to honor all United States Vietnam-era veterans who served on active duty in the U.S. Armed Forces between November 1, 1955, and May 15, 1975, regardless of location. All Vietnam-era veterans from the Second Congressional District of Connecticut will be eligible to take part in the ceremony and receive a Vietnam Veterans Lapel Pin. However, eligible veterans must register by March 15 to participate in the event and receive a pin.   If you are a Vietnam-era Veteran or know of a Vietnam-era veteran, I hope you will share this information. Please visit my website or call my office for more information: 860-886-0139

I am very pleased to have Valerie Nelson, the retired principal of the Groton’s National Blue Ribbon Award Winning Charles Barnum Elementary School joining me as my guest for the joint-address to Congress tonight.  At a time when many government leaders are now questioning the value of public education, Val’s incredible success leading the Barnum school stands as a towering example of the public system as its best. During Val’s tenure in 2010 and 2011, one-hundred percent of students from the third grade to the fifth grade scored as proficient or higher in the mathematics portion of the Connecticut Mastery Test. Her work is a testament to what public school administrators, teachers, and students can achieve with the right leadership and parental involvement that makes the Barnum school so extraordinary.   As a longtime member of the House Education and Workforce Committee, I know that our public education system is one of the primary drivers behind our country’s success over the past century. I will continue to oppose all efforts to undermine our public education system or divert badly needed resources to private schools that do not carry the same mission of equal service for all that our public schools carry out each day.

President Trump recently invited manufacturing CEOs to the White House for a discussion on creating jobs. What the CEO’s told Trump is that ‘jobs exist; skills don’t’ – meaning there is an unfilled need for thousands of manufacturing workers across the country but not enough qualified workers to fill that need. During President Obama’s term, we passed several important bills including the Workforce Investment Opportunity Act (WIOA) to provide funding for workforce training.   Unfortunately, the Republican Majority, which negotiated that bill with Obama, has never fully funded the programs under the law. If President Trump and the GOP majority in Congress are serious about putting people to work, then they will heed the advice from the business sector and fund workforce training programs to get Americans trained for the jobs of the future - just like we do in eastern Connecticut with the ‘manufacturing pipeline’.

Now that it has been revealed that Attorney General Jeff Sessions met with a Russian official during his time as a top surrogate for the Trump campaign, he must immediately recuse himself from all subsequent investigations into Russian meddling in our election and our government. This news is deeply troubling, and it cements the need for an independent, bipartisan investigation.

One thing is clear from yesterday's press conference: it was Mr. Sessions’ role as chairman of the Trump campaign's national security advisory committee, like Michael Flynn's similar role on the campaign, which piqued the Russian ambassador’s interest in meeting with him last September. This was not a routine meeting for a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Sessions’ decision to recuse himself now begs the question: who will be appointed as Special Counsel to handle the Justice Department’s inquiry into Russian influence in the 2016 election? Conducting this investigation is not a task for DOJ staff who work for the Attorney General.

Great news for eastern Connecticut: Electric Boat is telling its gigantic network of suppliers to prepare for even more work at the shipyard in the near future. Last week, I attended the annual submarine supplier’s conference in Washington to discuss the increase in work at EB and to explain why the outlook for continued submarine production is so strong. I have been a strong advocate for submarine construction for many years in my role leading the Seapower subcommittee in the House. Late last year, the Navy underscored the need for more attack submarines when it rolled out a brand new Force Structure Assessment that increased the requirement for attack submarines from 48-66. With nearly 500 suppliers across Connecticut working in support of shipbuilding at EB, this news means continued growth in our state's manufacturing sector for years to come.

Earlier today, I became the first member of the House of Representatives to speak out against the destructive anti-healthcare bill that Republican leadership released yesterday. After years of waiting patiently for Republicans to release their alternative to the Affordable Care Act, Speaker Ryan and his allies quietly introduced a bill late last night. Now, their plan is to rush it through committee mark-ups tomorrow, less than 48 hours after it was released, and vote on it without a single public hearing or budget analysis. This is an abuse of the legislative and democratic process.   Seven years ago when Democrats passed the ACA, we went through a 2-year process of hundreds of committee meetings, exhaustive markups that I personally participated in, and endless hours of floor debate. Only one thing is clear about this bill: Republicans DO NOT want you to know what is in it, or how it will radically change the protections for American families that were created under the ACA.

Cutting the Coast Guard’s budget in the name of immigration enforcement is more than shortsighted – it’s a sickening hit for the men and women who work every single day to protect our borders and our shores. The draft budget being circulated by the President’s Director of the Office of Management and Budget would undermine all of the progress that was made over the last several years to recapitalize Coast Guard cutters, rescue boats, and icebreakers. I will work with my colleagues on the bipartisan Coast Guard caucus to stop this destructive plan from ever being implemented.

Less than 48 hours after House Republicans released their healthcare proposal, they spent all night moving it through the committee process before the American people could learn what was included in the bill. Among other things, this bill is a massive tax break for millionaires that will raise costs for working families - rushing it through the legislative process at breakneck speed is a disservice to our citizens and an abuse of the democratic process.

I reintroduced my bipartisan bill this week to protect seniors on Medicare from facing massive costs for skilled nursing care after a hospital stay. Currently, seniors who are admitted for a hospital stay of 3-days or longer are provided with fully covered skilled nursing care for rehabilitation after they are discharged, unless the hospital labeled the patient as “under observation” instead of “admitted.” This small difference can cost patients tens of thousands of dollars in unexpected medical bills after leaving the hospital. My bill will change that rule so that any patient who stays in a hospital for 3 days or longer will receive full coverage for skilled nursing rehabilitation care afterward regardless of being designated as admitted or under observation.

This week, I was honored to participate in a very special ceremony for Ernest “Ernie” Maynard, a 92-year-old World War II veteran from Enfield, who was presented with a distinguished Belgian Fourragere - a ceremonial braid awarded by the Belgian Embassy for military service. Ernest served with the 2nd Armored Field Artillery Battalion in the 2nd United States Armored Division, during which time he participated in the historic Battle of the Bulge after coming through Normandy, France, two weeks after the D-Day invasion. Ernie has been a tireless supporter of veterans in the Enfield community, and he has worked with my office to make hundreds of presentations of the Ambassador for Peace medals issued by the South Korean government to American veterans of the Korean War. Ernie has made a practice of visiting area nursing homes and hospitals to provide company for fellow veterans. I want to thank the entire group from the 655th Regional Support Group Army Reserve, Connecticut Army National Guard and Commissioner Sean Connolly’s office from the Connecticut Department of VA affairs for making this ceremony possible.

TWO DAYS LEFT TO REGISTER: On March 24, I will be hosting a Vietnam Veterans 50th Commemoration Ceremony to honor all United States Vietnam-era veterans who served on active duty in the U.S. Armed Forces between November 1, 1955, and May 15, 1975, regardless of location. All Vietnam-era veterans from the Second Congressional District of Connecticut will be eligible to take part in the ceremony and receive a Vietnam Veterans Lapel Pin. However, eligible veterans must register by March 15 to participate in the event and receive a pin.   The Vietnam Veteran Lapel Pin is commemorative pin presented to Vietnam-era vets across the country as lasting memento signifying the thanks of the nation for their service and sacrifice. It was created by an act of Congress in 2008 during my first term as a member of the House Armed Services Committee.  If you are a Vietnam-era Veteran or know of a Vietnam-era veteran, I hope you will share this information. Please visit my website or call my office for more information: 860-886-0139

The report released by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office – whose numbers have been a favorite talking point of President Trump and Paul Ryan in the past – is a gut check for the American people. Many experts predicted over the last several days that “millions” of people would be knocked off of their coverage by the Republican plan.   The CBO report blows those predictions out of the water, confirming that 14 million people will lose healthcare within a year, with that number rising to 24 million by 2026. These are staggering numbers and it is time to listen to CBO, AMA, American Hospital Association, the Catholic Health Association, and many, many others who are warning Congress this bill is a disaster.

While the debate over the Republican health care bill - which would lead to higher premiums for seniors and knock 24 million people off their coverage – continues to make headlines, other troubling health bills are trickling up through committee. During a recent Education and Workforce meeting, a committee I sit on, the leadership pressed a so-called ‘wellness’ bill that would permit employers to impose harsh penalties on workers who refuse to participate in workplace sponsored genetic testing. The bill would allow employers to skirt federal genetic privacy and nondiscrimination laws to force employees to submit to genetic testing to track their overall health and fitness.   This is an almost inconceivable intrusion of a private citizen’s right to healthcare privacy and sounds like it is straight out of a science fiction novel. I immediately offered an amendment during that same meeting in an effort to mitigate some of the worst effects of this bill, but it was rejected. I ultimately voted against the bill that Republicans passed on a party line vote. You can read more about this troubling bill in a piece by the Washington Post: http://wapo.st/2msTKA6

Many people realize why the Republican health care bill would be harmful to working families, but are not aware of how harmful it would be for our nation’s seniors. First, the Republican bill would allow insurance companies to charge people over 60 years of age 500% more for coverage than younger people. Second, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and the Congressional Budget Office have estimated that the bill would speed up insolvency of the Medicare trust fund by several years – putting the future of Medicare in jeopardy. I stand with AARP, the AMA, American Hospital Association, the Catholic Health Association, and our seniors in opposition to this breathtakingly misguided bill.

The Kaiser Family Foundation has posted this excellent interactive map that shows a county-by-county impact of the Republican healthcare plan on Americans’ premium assistance. Middle-income seniors in New London, Windham, Tolland, and Middlesex counties will lose thousands of dollars towards their health insurance premiums if the Republican “replace” bill, the American Health Care Act, becomes law.   Those over 50 years old in these counties will all see a decrease in premium assistance of at least 45% ($3,230/yr) if their income is $50,000, and as high as 67% if their income is $30,000 ($5,850/yr). The loss of that type of help will make insurance coverage an impossibility. This localized, real life harm is the reason why the American Medical Association, The American Nurses Association, The American Hospital Association, AARP and many others are pleading with Congress to block passage of the “repeal” bill and go back to the drawing board.

I spoke on the House floor yesterday to implore my Republican colleagues to slow down and consider the destructive consequences that will impact millions of families across the country if they pass their healthcare repeal later this week. Republicans are being told by Paul Ryan and Donald Trump that this a wonderful healthcare bill, and something that won’t hurt people and won’t make them worse off financially, but when you look at any of the data being presented by independent groups and agencies it is clear that the opposite is true. The CBO is telling us this, the doctors are telling us this, the nurses are telling us this, the hospitals are telling us this, and those who advocate for older Americans are telling us this. It is not too late. It is time to listen to the people who are closest to the system and stop this rush to harming millions of Americans.

Today is a pivotal moment in the history of our country as the Congress decides whether or not Americans have a right to affordable, quality health coverage, or whether people who cannot afford insurance should simply go without it. Make no mistake: this bill will impact every American, not just those who rely on the insurance exchanges and Medicaid. It rolls back provisions that guarantee insurance companies cannot charge women more money than men, must include ambulatory patient care and emergency services in ALL of their plans, and provide pediatric care, prescription drug coverage, and laboratory services as essential benefits. When Republicans tell you they are lowering premiums – they are not. Instead, they are simply allowing issuance companies to once again sell subpar and inadequate policies at cut-rate prices.    Since Speaker Ryan and House Republicans introduced their long-overdue health care proposal just 2 short weeks ago, the overwhelming consensus from medical organizations, patients’ rights groups, and advocates for senior citizens has been that this bill will be a disaster for tens of millions of Americans across the country. And yet, despite calls from their own moderate members, the Republican leadership and Donald Trump are determined to railroad this bill through Congress tonight. This bill has made a mockery of our democratic process. I urge my Republican colleagues to slow down and listen to the health care practitioners who know what's best for their patients and take this bill back to the drawing board.

Overnight, a new development surfaced regarding the Republicans' healthcare bill which adds to the harm it will inflict on our nation. VoteVets, a highly respected veterans’ advocacy group issued an alert that the bill will strip healthcare insurance tax credits from veterans. According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, this change will harm 8 million veterans who are eligible for VA health services, but get healthcare through other means.  In addition, the Paralyzed Veterans of America issued a statement criticizing the bill’s cuts to Medicare and Medicaid which provide essential coverage to many more veterans. This bill which nurses, doctors, and hospitals, have warned will hurt America’s healthcare system, will now also hurt millions of our country’s citizens who have served in uniform.

Yesterday evening, my office hosted a ceremony in Norwich to honor more than 100 Vietnam-era veterans during the 50th commemoration of the Vietnam War. I unfortunately had to miss the event because of late votes in Washington, DC, but my staff veterans’ representative Manuel Meneses joined Capt. Paul Whitescarver, commanding officer of the SUBASE in Groton, and Thomas Burke, an Army veteran from Norwich to present Vietnam Veteran Lapel Pins as a lasting memento of our nation’s thanks. These pins were created by an act of Congress in 2008 during my first my term as a member of the House Armed Services Committee.   Eastern Connecticut is proud to be home to the highest number of veterans in Connecticut. There are over 60,000 veterans residing in eastern Connecticut and nearly 22,000 served during the Vietnam-era. I am glad my office was able to join the national effort to honor our Vietnam veterans. We will be holding additional Vietnam pin events over the next year and anyone interested in participating can learn more by calling my Norwich office at 860-886-0139.

I will be holding a live telephone town hall tomorrow night starting at 6:30 PM for constituents across the Second District. Some of the issues that will be discussed are the budget, the future of healthcare, Social Security, and Medicare. If you would like to participate in this event, please follow the link below to my website. You can also live-stream the event by using the same link tomorrow.

URGENT: This afternoon we will be voting on an outrageous bill that will strike down privacy protections that the FCC adopted last year to protect your personal information and internet activity. The FCC rule created under the Obama Administration is intended to ensure that the large telecom and cable internet providers like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T cannot use their power to sweep up information about internet activity and sell it to third-parties. It mandates that information like geographic location, information about your children, health, finances, Social Security number, internet and app usage, cannot be released, sold, or monetized without your consent. I understand that Americans expect their internet service providers to protect their privacy and keep them in control of their personal information. I vehemently oppose this effort to strike the privacy rule down, and will vote no.

I’m live from DC with tonight’s telephone town hall! You can click the web page below to join us via live stream. You can also submit a written question. Looking forward to a great hour of hearing from my constituents.  Update: This event has now ended, but as always you can contact my office through my website by clicking here: https://courtney.house.gov/contact

I, along with the thousands of constituents who contacted my office yesterday, was stunned when the House of Representatives voted to undo a landmark privacy safeguard intended to protect Americans’ online data. I voted NO and strongly encouraged my colleagues to join me, but the bill was ultimately passed on a party-line vote even though several Republicans crossed the aisle to vote with Democrats. It is hard to understand why this bill was considered a top priority during a time when I believe Americans feel like their privacy and personal information is under siege from all directions.   I recognize that Americans expect the government and their internet service providers to protect their privacy and keep them in control of their data, and that is why I vehemently opposed this effort. I promise to continue to work on rebuilding our internet data safeguards to return a sense of personal privacy to Americans in rapidly changing world.

In an interview with CBS which aired earlier today, Speaker Paul Ryan made it clear that he has absolutely no desire to work with Democrats on a bipartisan basis to improve our healthcare system. This is an extremely unfortunate position for Speaker Ryan to put himself in given how important healthcare reform is to people across this country, regardless of geography or political affiliation. I remain ready and willing to work with my colleagues and to go back to the drawing board, using a deliberative and open process with hearings, amendments, and CBO analysis to build on and improve the Affordable Care Act. What the American people want us to do is work together to fix the law, not turn the clock back under the guise of “repeal and replace”.

I was honored to meet with the Submarine Junior Officers of the Year who are chosen annually to recognize emerging leaders in our Navy. Notably, the group included female junior officers who are pioneering the integration of women into our undersea fleet. We talked about submarine construction, how the House Armed Services Committee works on defense issues, and the issues they will face as leaders in the fleet. We also spent some time reviewing the Navy’s new shipbuilding plan created under the prior administration which calls for a large increase in submarine production. As always, I was impressed with the questions from these talented men and women - our nation is well served with them leading our submarine force.

It was an honor to visit Korean War veteran Roger McCully at his home on Friday. My office assisted him in securing seven medals he earned as Marine Corps Sergeant during the height of the conflict 1951-53, including Korean Service Medal with 3 Bronze campaign stars. He headed the Marine flight crew at the Pohang airfield, designated at the time as K-3 for the 1st Marine Aircraft Wing. Roger shared with me that among the pilots his crew kept safe, was none other than former Red Sox slugger Ted Williams and John Glenn, who went on to be the path-breaking astronaut and Ohio US Senator. His daughter shared with me the attached picture of Sgt. McCully strapping in Ted Williams as he set out on one of his 39 missions. His account of his conversations with both- talking fishing and flying were fascinating.  After leaving active duty Roger returned stateside, and spent 36 years at Pratt and Whitney, contributing to our nation's air superiority and raising a beautiful family. It was a delightful visit and his story military service is a great piece of Connecticut history.

Over the last two years, the AmeriCorps program has stood up veteran coffeehouses all across the Second District providing a regular meeting place and support programs for eastern Connecticut veterans. At the coffeehouses, vets regularly discuss everyday issues like access to hearing aids, disability benefits, VA updates, and medal recovery ceremonies which have occurred because of the coffeehouse gatherings. Connecting veterans to hard-earned benefits is a real success story for this largely volunteer-driven operation.   Unfortunately, funding cuts proposed in the president’s budget blueprint issued earlier this month would put these coffeehouses at risk. During a hearing on the AmeriCorps program at the Education and the Workforce Committee last week, I raised the alarm about the harm the Trump budget would cause to this very low-cost volunteer-driven effort to help veterans. This program would be completely eliminated under the president’s budget proposal. I pledge to continue to fight to preserve this vital funding for Senior Corps and other federally-funded service programs so they can continue to carry out work on behalf of vets in eastern Connecticut.

Today is #EqualPay Day- but it is not an occasion to celebrate. This is the day that a woman’s wages would finally catch up to what a man earned during the previous calendar year in the same job. Women who work full time still only earn only 80 cents for every dollar earned by men, and the pay gap is even worse for women of color. It’s 63 cents for every dollar earned by men for African American women and 54 cents for Latinas. It is especially outrageous that women can serve alongside men in combat roles in the armed services, yet still have to fight for pay equity in the private sector back home. Shockingly, the pay gap actually increases for women with advanced degrees, contrary to what many people expect.  My colleague Rosa DeLauro has once again introduced the Paycheck Fairness Act, as she has done at outset of each new Congress since 1997 and I am proud to be an original cosponsor again this Congress. We need to finally pass this bill so we never have to mark another #EqualPayDay again.

The yearend labor report for 2015-2016 released a few days ago confirms continued long-term job growth across eastern Connecticut. This report released by CTDOL shows that the Norwich–New London region grew faster than any other part of the state - and the expansion will not be slowing down anytime soon. As noted in the report, much of the growth is driven by the surge in hiring at Electric Boat in 2015-2016, and the ripple effect that increasing submarine production is having on the yard’s supplier base of nearly 500 manufacturers across the region and state. EB will continue hiring for years to come as submarine construction continues to increase, resulting in 14,000 new hires over the next 15 years. This report confirms the benefit of Congressional actions I have taken as the ranking member of the House Seapower Subcommittee to boost the Virginia-class and Columbia-class submarine programs over the last eight years.

After last night’s air strikes in Syria, it is clear that this is no time for Congress to be on the sidelines. Speaker Ryan should call the House back in session immediately to take up its constitutional responsibility to debate authorization of any additional military force.   The missile strikes on the Syrian military air base appear to be a proportionate response to Assad’s despicable use of sarin gas on his own citizens, a violation of international law. Further engagement in this conflict, however, risks escalation that has the potential to carry serious consequences for the United States, including direct confrontation with Russia, Syria’s backer. We need a comprehensive, diplomatic, and deliberate approach to addressing this crisis.

Last Friday I had a great visit to the extended learning program at Samuel Huntington Elementary School in Norwich. This after-school program is a true success story that has improved attendance, behavior, and engagement for students. It is also a program that could lose its funding under the Trump budget, which de-funds the federal 21st Century afterschool program. This is the kind of real-world impact that makes clear the devastating consequences of the budget being proposed in Washington.

Yesterday I had a great visit to The Last Green Valley, a National Heritage Corridor that spans 1,100 square miles and includes 26 towns in northeastern Connecticut. This beautiful valley is the only stretch of dark night sky between Boston and DC, and is preserved by a cooperative of private citizens, businesses, nonprofits and local governments. But its funding is at risk due to the Trump Administration’s budget proposal, which eliminates funding for all 49 of our country’s National Heritage Areas.   Losing this funding would be a major hit to the preservation of The Last Green Valley, and would have a long-lasting negative impact on similar areas across the nation. I joined with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to request that this funding stay in place. Thank you to Lois Bruinooge and the rest of the team  for being gracious hosts and for preserving the Valley for eastern Connecticut.

I recently paid a visit to the Noank Aquaculture Cooperative to highlight the destructive impact that President Trump’s proposed elimination of the 50-year-old Sea Grant program will have on local fishermen, shellfish farmers, and maritime conservation efforts in Long Island Sound. With more than 90 percent of the seafood consumed in the U.S. being imported from foreign countries, the federal Sea Grant program has succeeded in jump-starting Connecticut fisheries in Groton and Norwalk. The Sea Grant program at the UConn Avery Point campus assists local producers and local communities by connecting them with resources and best practices to restore a healthy maritime community.   These types of successful investments would simply not be possible without support from Sea Grant, which operates in 49 other sites around the country. I recently led and organized a coalition of 100 bipartisan members of the House of Representatives on a letter urging continued support for this vital program as the budget process moves ahead after Easter break. The proposed elimination of Sea Grant by the administration is a counterproductive, anti-growth measure that I will work to stop.

I joined volunteers with the Thames Valley Council for Community Action earlier this week as they prepared and delivered food to local seniors from 'Meals on Wheels'. The Meals on Wheels program provides tens-of-thousands of seniors across our state with food assistance each week, but it is facing elimination under President Trump’s proposed budget. While working with the volunteers, I saw firsthand what a difference the program makes in the lives of senior citizens who may have trouble getting to the grocery store or regularly preparing their own hot meals.   Last year, the Meals on Wheels program prepared a record 2.1 million meals serving more than 22,000 elderly residents in Connecticut alone. I joined a number of my colleagues from both sides of the aisle recently in writing a letter urging continued support for this vital program as the budget process moves ahead after Easter break. I pledge to continue to work to stop President Trump’s destructive budget cuts that will hurt Americans across the country.

As many know, Congress is on break this week and I have used this time at home to listen and meet with constituents to get their perspective on developments in Washington. One particular concern that I have heard repeatedly is about the release of the 2018 preliminary budget by the Trump administration that contains drastic spending cuts that will eliminate services which have been part of the fabric of eastern Connecticut for decades. For example, Meals on Wheels for the elderly, Sea Grant which assists local fishermen, medical research at the National Institutes of Health which funds important work at the University of Connecticut, brownfield cleanup grants through the EPA, drinking water and wastewater projects through the USDA, and the 21st Century After School Program are set to be eliminated or drastically cut under the proposed Trump budget.  Many of these programs, such as Meals on Wheels, Sea Grant, and USDA Rural Development are over 50 years old. As the Norwich Bulletin points out, this budget may seem far away in Washington, but if it were ever passed its impacts back home would be devastating. I will continue to work with all of my colleagues from both sides of the aisle to ensure that this destructive budget never becomes law.

I had a great conversation with Al Terzi on The Real Story over the weekend. We covered a number of critical topics including Syria, Russia, North Korea, the federal budget and the recent state labor report which showed that the Norwich-New London job market was the fastest growing in Connecticut from 2015-2016. The main driver behind the strong job growth remains the increasing work at Electric Boat and its network of suppliers that I am proud to support in my role as the ranking member of the Seapower subcommittee.

I was pleased to join the Pawcatuck Neighborhood Center late last week during a ribbon cutting ceremony for brand new equipment that will allow them to enhance their nutrition assistance programs for local families in need. PNC is a small community-based non-profit that operates various food programs, such as ‘Meals on Wheels’, for clients across southeastern Connecticut. The new refrigeration units will replace a dozen smaller, less energy efficient units that have been in use for many years. With the new units, PNC will be able to consolidate its stock of frozen food stores in one location to exapnd services they provide for local families and seniors. I would like to recognize Vicki Anderson the outgoing executive director of PNC, who is retiring after 15 years of dedicated service to her community. Vicki has been an unrivaled asset to our region and I thank her for the wonderful work she carried out during her many years of service. I was also happy to stand next to my predecessor Rob Simmons during the ribbon cutting ceremony.

It was an honor to join the Connecticut National Guard for the groundbreaking of the 14th Civil Support Team Ready Building in Windsor Locks yesterday. Construction of this state-of-the-art facility was paid for with $11 million in federal funding that originated in the 2016 budget from the Readiness Subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee which I have been a member of since 2007. The new 23,700 square foot building will support 22 full-time personnel from the 14th Civil Support Team and will provide significant upgrades from their previous building.  The new facility will have classrooms, vehicle bays, communication rooms, equipment storage facilities, and administrative spaces. This project is part of a series of infrastructure improvements totaling over 150 million dollars for the Connecticut National Guard over the last 8 years. General Thad Martin and his team are great partners in our work ensure that Connecticut gets a fair share of military construction resources from the Department of Defense. This work is transforming Connecticut’s Guard to take on new missions in the 21st century.

Earlier this week voters in Preston approved the final sale of the Norwich Hospital site that will allow redevelopment plans by the Mohegan tribe to move forward. This project is going to have a positive impact across southeastern Connecticut and it is a strong affirmation that years of hard work by a number of regional partners is now paying off. I am proud that my office was part of the team that led the effort to obtain federal brownfields grant funding from the EPA starting in 2009. This critical funding paid for the extensive environmental cleanup operation that was necessary to prepare the hospital site for redevelopment. First Selectman Bob Congdon deserves recognition for his steady leadership throughout this process and for getting the project to this point. The decision to collaborate with the Mohegan tribe, whose roots in the area go back centuries, shows an enduring commitment to working with regional partners.

The latest Connecticut employment report shows that southeastern Connecticut remains the fastest growing jobs market in the state. Last month, the Connecticut Department of Labor released an end-of-year report showing that the Norwich-New London region was the fastest growing market from 2015-2016.   A major factor behind these gains is increased submarine production at Electric Boat and across its network of 500 suppliers. As of yesterday afternoon, there were 196 job openings at the shipyard alone. I pledge to continue to support additional submarines and work at EB in my role as ranking member on the HASC Seapower subcommittee in Congress.

New data show that the real estate market in eastern Connecticut is continuing to thrive. The rise in local home sales and home values can be attributed directly to the improving job market locally and new work in the manufacturing sector related to production at Electric Boat. The New London-Norwich region has been experiencing the fastest rate of job growth in Connecticut since 2015.    We saw home sales across the Second Congressional District increase by 12% in 2016 and the numbers for 2017 are off to a strong start this year. Another recent piece in The Day discusses how the downtown New London market is ‘sizzling’: http://bit.ly/2oDV58i

Interesting New York Times piece today uses reports from the Department of Energy to outline where clean energy jobs exist today. The state-by-state report from January shows that in Connecticut, solar electricity generation now accounts for a higher percentage of the electricity generation workforce than any other fuel including natural gas. Out of roughly 5,000 people employed in electricity generation across our state, nearly 3,000 work in solar generation in some capacity.   Clean energy jobs are not only going to dominate our economy in the future – they are already a major part of our economy right now. Instead of desperately attempting to revive fossil fuel jobs that are likely gone forever, we should be investing money in clean technology and workforce training to move people into these valuable clean energy jobs.

As the ranking member of the Seapower subcommittee, I recently had the opportunity to travel to San Diego to visit the captain and crew of the USS Connecticut and take a daylong ride to view the ship’s impressive array of capabilities. The Connecticut is one of only three Seawolf-class submarines ever built and has special features including faster speed, deeper diving ability, and greater firepower than any other attack submarine in our fleet. The motto of the Connecticut is “Arsenal of the Nation”.  It had been a while since Connecticut’s namesake ship had a visitor from the state so I brought them a few special treats including Connecticut shaped chocolate bars from our own Munson's Chocolates, a pennant from the University of Connecticut, and a basketball signed by Geno Auriemma and the record-setting 2017 UConn women’s basketball team. It was great visiting with Commander Brian Taddiken and his crewmembers, many of whom hail from Connecticut and have served at the Groton SUBASE. During the same trip, I also had the opportunity to tour two Navy shipyards in the San Diego area and receive a briefing by Vice Admiral Tom Rowden, Commander of Naval Surface Forces, on the state of fleet readiness in Asia Pacific region.

Betsy DeVos’ decision to roll back Obama-era protections for student loan borrowers was anti-borrower, and yesterday I joined 130 of my colleagues to send her a letter expressing our adamant opposition. We already have a generation hamstrung by student loan debt: 1 in 4 student loan borrowers are in default or delinquent on their federal student loans. We should be working to ensure that borrowers are not exploited by abusive and predatory lenders.   The consumer protections that Secretary DeVos nixed required that lenders communicate clearly and promptly, and provided an unprecedented level of transparency to the federal student loan program. It was all too obvious during her confirmation process that Secretary DeVos was not qualified to hold this trusted position, and this bizarre decision only hurts the students she promised to protect. We deserve better.

Almost a million veterans and their families lacked health insurance before the Affordable Care Act was passed. Now, thanks to the ACA, that number has dropped by 40%. Repealing the law now would jeopardize the health insurance of many people who have worn the uniform of this nation.

The American public woke up this morning to the news that House Republicans will again attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act this week after their toxic health care bill was suddenly pulled from the floor a month ago. Sadly, instead of doing the obvious and working with Democrats on a compromise, Speaker Paul Ryan publicly ruled out a bipartisan process and is instead putting forward a hyper-partisan fix known as “Amendment 25” in an effort to win over more votes within his conference.   In a nutshell, the amendment would allow states to strike Essential Health Benefits from insurance policies, weakening coverage for maternity care, behavioral health services, and emergency room care. The American Hospital Association, which represents thousands of hospitals across America, stated: ‘the amendment proposed this week would dramatically worsen the bill.’ The AHA was joined by the March of Dimes, the American Cancer Society, the AMA, and the American Nurses Association along with many, many other healthcare advocates in condemning this amendment.    If this bill is brought to the floor this week, there will not be enough time for a revised analysis by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office on its impact to the healthcare market or the federal budget. When the CBO issued its report on the first version of the AHCA, it showed that it would throw more than 24 million people off the coverage rolls within 10 years. I went to the floor today to speak out against this modified bill and publicly warn my colleagues that America’s hospitals, doctors, nurses, and patient advocates should be heeded: this bill will cause disastrous harm.

I hope you and your family can join me on Thursday night for our annual Congressional Art Competition reception. The annual event for high school artists will be held on May 4th at 6:30 PM at the Slater Museum in the Norwich Free Academy. More than 50 students from across eastern Connecticut have submitted pieces for the competition this year. The winner will be flown to Washington, D.C. for our national ceremony in June and their artwork will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol building for one year. The event is open to the public, so come support our local students and view the wonderful artworks below along with many others.
Please take a moment to watch my statement on the effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act today in the House of Representatives.

I had a great time visting with students and parents from around the Second District last night at our annual Congressional Arts Competition, held this year at the Norwich Free Academy. Congratulations to the winner: Ariel Miner of RHAM High School in Hebron. Ariel’s artwork will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol building for one year alongside other winners from around the country. I would also like to thank all of the other students for participating and making this year’s reception such a success. Thank you to our judges, Joy Supples, an art teacher at Ella T. Grasso Tech High School, and Sandra Jeknavorian, an associated professor at Three Rivers Community College, for their support of the competition and our young artists.

There was some great news for local electronics parts supplier TTM Technologies Inc. in Stafford. The Journal Inquirer is reporting that the company is off to strong start in 2017 with increased sales and probability. I recently visited one of their two facilities in the Stafford area to see firsthand how increasing submarine production and other defense contracting work in support of our nation’s defense is helping to fuel growth. Over the past year, TTM has added over 100 employees to their two northeast Connecticut locations bringing their workforce up to 720 employees.    As one of the nearly 500 manufacturing firms operating across the state and region in support of submarine production, TTM is playing a key role in supplying Electric Boat to meet the demands of the Virginia-class program and the upcoming Columbia-class program. As someone who has worked hard to boost submarine investment, it is exciting for me to see the reach of this work extend across eastern Connecticut.

Great piece in The Day highlighting the renovations that are underway to turn historic Ponemah Mill in Taftville into a complex of 200-plus apartments. The Ponemah Mill, originally known as the Taftville Mill, opened in 1866 as a major cotton textile factory operating along the Shetucket River north of downtown Norwich. The mill operated for more than 100 years, employing generations of local residents and immigrants until it was shuttered in the late twentieth-century.   The beautiful old building, built in the architectural style known as ‘Second Empire’, sat unused and abandoned for many years following the closure. The site is a perfect example of a project using the federal historic tax credit which I have supported in Congress. The new development should be an asset to the Taftville area for many years to come.

I recently launched the bipartisan ‘Friends of Australia Caucus’ with my Republican colleague Mike Gallagher from Wisconsin. The timing was no coincidence, as we commemorated the 75th anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea where the U.S. and Australian navies fought side-by-side to protect Australia from the advancing Japanese forces. Our national alliance with the Australians has been strengthening ever since that shared experience.  The United States and Australia share a close economic partnership and free trade agreement that facilitates more than $65 billion in annual trade of goods and services. Our mutual defense agreement remains one of the most important strategic alliances in the entire Indo-Pacific region. According to Australian Parliament, this enduring alliance is Australia’s most important defense relationship, and it has been fostered and strengthened through increased information sharing, personal exchanges, joint-exercises, overseas basing, and shared engagement throughout the region.  I recently joined the US Department of Commerce Trade Representative for Connecticut and local businesses to announce an aerospace and defense Trade Promotion Initiative with the Government of Australia.

The Coast Guard has long been the only branch of the military that lacks a museum to celebrate its contributions to our national security. Last week, we were able to secure $5 million in federal funds toward the construction of a planned museum in New London. This funding is a direct result of an effort I helped lead in 2014 to change a federal law that blocked any funding for the museum. This investment provides a critical boost to the development efforts already underway, and sends a powerful signal that this effort has the strong backing of Congress and the Coast Guard.

The sudden and non-transparent firing of Director James Comey who was spearheading the investigation of Russian influence in the 2016 election does not pass the smell test. The 10-year-term for an FBI director was intentionally created to avoid this kind of rash turnover. President Trump's explanation that it was based on Attorney General Sessions’ recommendation - a political appointee who barely survived Senate confirmation - does little to reassure the country and if anything raises more doubt about the motives of this stunning development.  It is painfully clear that we need an immediate and independent investigation of all aspects relating to Russia's meddling in our election. We need a review that the American people can have faith in.

The Los Angeles Times today pinpointed the grave consequences of President Trump's rash firing of the person leading the investigation into Russian interference during the 2016 election that benefitted his campaign. If the president's advisors are innocent, as he has repeatedly claimed, than there is nothing to fear from an independent investigation to determine the extent of Russian activities. As Republican Senator John McCain has stated, the president's decision to remove the FBI Director only confirms the urgent need for an independent investigative committee.

Today, I am joining more than 60 of my colleagues in sending a bipartisan letter to President Donald Trump’s Budget Director, Mick Mulvaney, strongly opposing any funding cut for the Office of National Drug Control Policy, known as ONDCP. Last year, I hosted the Director of ONDCP, otherwise known as the 'Drug Czar,' in eastern Connecticut to learn about the destructive opioid epidemic gripping our region and the country. ONDCP is responsible for leading federal drug policy efforts with a focus on innovations in drug abuse prevention, criminal justice, treatment, and recovery.  Recently, the New York Times published a disturbing report that the Trump administration may be considering cutting funding for ONDCP by 95% in next year’s budget. I would urge the president’s key advisors to meet with local law enforcement officials battling drug abuse on the front lines and rule out any funding cut for drug abuse and treatment efforts.

Amidst the whirlwind of revelations in recent days, there remains a common thread: the influence of Russia in the 2016 election. Whether it was President Trump admitting that he fired FBI Director Comey over "the Russia thing," or the sharing of highly classified intelligence with the Russian ambassador and foreign minister, or last night’s report that Trump may have asked Comey to call off the FBI investigation of Michael Flynn's contacts with Russian officials - all of these individual events point to a deeply disturbing pattern of links with the Russian government and attempts to impede the FBI investigation of Russian activities.   Today, I will sign a discharge petition to force the House to take up a bill to create a thorough, nonpartisan, and truly independent commission to fully investigate this troubling range of issues. The credibility of our democracy, our law enforcement agencies, and our standing in the world is at stake.

I joined Senator Elizabeth Warren yesterday to reintroduce the Bank on Students Emergency Loan Refinancing Act in the House and Senate. Our bill would allow people with existing high-interest student loans to refinance them to a lower rate just as they can with home loans, car loans, and credit card debt. Middle-class families in this country are crying out for relief from the crushing burden of student debt and Congress should pass our bill right away. I promise to continue to bring this up every chance I can until we get this done. #HigherEdNotDebt #BankOnStudents

American manufacturers have been repeating the same message: Jobs are there, skills are not. Those six simple words express the challenge employers have been experiencing across the country, and both sides of the aisle have heard the message loud and clear. The skills gap is real, and it is wide. That is why I joined my colleagues on the Education & Workforce committee in responding to this challenge by passing the Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act earlier this week.  This bipartisan bill that I’m cosponsoring authorizes a significant increase in funding of Career and Technical Education programs. With the resurgence of manufacturing in eastern Connecticut, thanks to the increased workload at Electric Boat and over 200 small parts manufacturers throughout our region, it is more important than ever that we pass this legislation, close the skills gap, and ensure that eastern Connecticut residents are filling eastern Connecticut jobs.

There was an important new development for homeowners impacted by crumbling foundations yesterday. The National Tax Payer Advocate who works within the IRS publicly stated that they are requesting federal tax relief for homeowners harmed by crumbling foundations. This was a result of a joint effort between my office and Rep. John Larson's office to engage with the IRS over last 6 months. We still have a lot of work to do, but having a key federal official publicly acknowledge the merits of casualty loss tax assistance for local homeowners is an encouraging development.

The Trump budget released yesterday fails middle-class and working-class families on many levels, but some of the most egregious cuts have to do with programs that support higher education affordability. The budget effectively dismantles the Subsidized Stafford Loan Program by forcing students to pay interest on their loans WHILE they are still in school. The change to Subsidized Stafford Loans alone would cost students and families across the country $39 billion over 10 years. If that was not bad enough, the budget would also decimate the Federal Work Study Program that helps low-income students work part-time while obtaining a college degree, and eliminates the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program aimed at helping nurses, police, teachers and primary care doctors pay for college and graduate school. If the framework the president proposed yesterday were ever to become law, it would deliver a devastating blow to our economy and working families across this country.
