Memorial Day weekend is a reminder of the care and benefits that all of our veterans earned for their courage and sacrifice. I am honored to be an original cosponsor of the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act, which extends medical coverage for Agent Orange exposure to Navy veterans who were exposed to the chemical in the waters around Vietnam. The widespread use of Agent Orange caused it to contaminate the water these veterans used for showering, drinking, laundry, and cooking, exposing around 90,000 Navy sailors with the toxic chemical.   Unfortunately, the VA continues to interpret the Agent Orange Act of 1991, which first established a presumption of exposure for those who served in Vietnam, as including only veterans who actually set foot on land or served on the inland waterways of Vietnam. Since 2007, I have supported legislation to fix this problem finally by specifying in law that those who served off the coast of Vietnam should receive the same presumption of exposure to Agent Orange as other Vietnam veterans. This is a national disgrace that must be corrected.

Memorial Day reminds us of the wartime sacrifices that took place not just on the battlefield, but all across the country and through all levels of the armed services. This week, I was pleased to join my colleague Rep. Nita Lowey from New York as an original cosponsor help secure veterans benefits for the heroic women who supported American military effort in World War II by joining the United States Cadet Nurse Corps. There was a shortage of nurses both in the armed services and in communities across the country when U.S. involvement in the war began. To address this, Congress authorized $150 million to establish the Cadet Nurse Corps program in 1943.   In an unusual move for the time, the program provided funding for nursing schools and students of all racial and ethnic backgrounds. Over 124,000 women enrolled in the program and received free tuition with the condition that they complete their education within 30 months and work as nurses for the duration of the war. As the Norwich Bulletin recently reported, Elizabeth Yeznach who is an 89-year-old Ledyard resident and retired nursing instructor at Ella T. Grasso Southeastern Technical High School is a veteran of the Cadet Nurses Corps. These women played a vital and honorable role during one of our nation’s most trying times, and I am proud to support this bipartisan legislation that would see them receive the benefits that they earned.

On Memorial Day, we pause to honor our troops, our veterans, and those who paid the ultimate price while serving our nation abroad. I am proud to represent the district with the highest veteran population in Connecticut, and I will continue to make it my mission to ensure they receive the care and benefits they have earned. Thank you to all of past and present members of our armed services for your courage and bravery.

I was honored to remember two local heroes, Specialist Jacob Martir and First Lieutenant Keith Heidtman, during our Memorial Day ceremony in Norwich yesterday. Both of these individuals paid the ultimate price while serving in the military during the Iraq War. Jacob was lost on August 18, 2004, when he was struck by small-arms fire while patrolling the Sadr City neighborhood in Baghdad, and Keith was lost on May 28, 2007, after sustaining serious injuries when his helicopter was shot down.   I had the opportunity to read from a commemorative letter my office recently helped obtain from Lieutenant Heidtman’s former commanding general, retired General David H. Petraeus, honoring Keith’s sacrifice, but the sentiments he expressed can be applied to all of our nation’s heroes lost in combat. One portion of the letter reads as follows: “We must never forget the sacrifice of Lieutenant Heidtman and all the others who gave their lives for our country. They made the ultimate sacrifice fighting to defend freedoms and ideals that generations of Americans have cherished and generations of Americans have fought to protect. … They are heroes and we must always cherish the extraordinary sacrifices they made for our country.” If you have a moment, you can read the full letter from General Petraeus here: http://bit.ly/2rRMXqn

The Hartford Courant completed an important four-part editorial series on the crisis of crumbling foundations affecting homeowners across north-central Connecticut today. Together, the series reflects the devastating toll this problem is taking on our local communities and makes the need for immediate action. The final piece released today outlines specific steps that should be taken right away, including federal tax relief that I am working on along with Congressman John Larson. Along with federal housing funds that I identified last summer that can be allocated by the State of Connecticut, I have been working hard to identify possible sources of federal support for this problem. However, as the Courant’s series makes clear, addressing this crisis will take a multi-faceted approach on the local, state and federal levels – and action is needed now. I will continue to do all I can on the federal level to support efforts by state officials to assist homeowners and communities struggling with crumbling foundations.

After ten years of US leadership, bringing together 140 nations to sign the Paris Accord in 2015, President Trump threw it all away and isolated our nation to the company of Syria and Nicaragua as holdouts to a global response to a global problem. President Trump failed to remember or understand that it was global action that eliminated Chlorofluorocarbons from the destroying the earth's ozone layer and smart regulation that stopped sulfur dioxide (acid rain) from destroying our nation's environment.  This decision is not only taking us backward, it also fails to capitalize on the growing industry being built around clean and renewable energy that is creating jobs right here in Connecticut.  In January, the Department of Energy released state-by-state statistics on employment in the energy sector which showed that solar energy jobs now account for a higher percentage of the electricity generation workforce in Connecticut than any other fuel source including natural gas.  Out of roughly 5,000 people employed in electricity generation across our state, nearly 3,000 work in solar energy in some capacity. Clean energy jobs are not only going to dominate our economy in the future – they are already a major part of our economy right now. Instead of desperately attempting to revive fossil fuel jobs that are likely gone forever, we should be investing money in clean technology and workforce training to move people into these valuable clean energy jobs.

This positive “one-time” effort was unveiled during my questioning of acting Under Secretary Allison Stiller at a Seapower subcommittee hearing on May 24 in Washington. My office has been working with Electric Boat over the last year to convey to the Navy the urgency of addressing the delays in processing new hires. We have raised this concern repeatedly by letter, in person, and at Seapower subcommittee hearings such as the recent one. The Navy's decision to deploy reservists to supplement the clearance system is a powerful statement about the commitment of the Navy and Congress to enabling the critical work being performed in Groton and Quonset Point. As ranking member of the Seapower Subcommittee, I will continue to use my position to advance the recapitalization of our undersea force as well as boosting the workforce in Eastern Connecticut.

President Donald Trump’s budget seeks to slash federal programs that reduce higher education costs for families in eastern Connecticut and across the country. The Trump Budget would eliminate the in-school interest subsidies for Stafford Student Loans, freeze Pell grants, eliminate the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program, and significantly reduce federal work-study funds. Together, these proposals would dramatically increase college costs and make the already dire student loan crisis even worse.   In 2015, 70% of college seniors graduated with debt. This year, more than one in four borrowers is in delinquency or in default on their student loans. The worsening student debt crisis shows no signs of slowing down, and threatens the futures of young people all across America. They cannot invest in our economy, buy a home, or start a small business. I am urging President Trump to reconsider many of the proposals in his budget, particularly those impacting access to college aid, and to uphold his campaign promises to fight for the middle-class rather than cutting their lifelines. I promise to keep fighting for higher education affordability so that the dream of a college degree remains within reach for Connecticut families.

In fact, my first speech in Congress was on the ‘College Cost Reduction Act’ in 2007 that created this program after being signed into law by President George W. Bush.    On Monday, I held an event with students and community stakeholders in Hartford, including a local doctor who said she may not have made the financial commitment to enter medicine without the promise that her substantial student loans would eventually be forgiven for her service.

As the Trump Budget continues to be analyzed and scrubbed, new and even more disturbing proposals continue to emerge. In particular, the Military Order of the Purple Heart, USA, a national veteran’s organization just sent an urgent alert criticizing the administration for proposing the elimination of Individual Unemployability benefits for veterans age 62 and older. As AMVETS recently noted: "these veterans have largely been disabled, out of the workforce and not paying into Social Security for many years before reaching 65. I think it is important for my district to know that I immediately joined a bipartisan group of House members adamantly opposing this measure. There is no justification for arbitrarily disqualifying working age veterans from collecting unemployment benefits they have earned through their own payroll tax contributions. I will continue to work with the Military Order of the Purple Heart to block this measure from seeing the light of day.

Over the last 5 years, as the U.S. economy has been slowly healing, employers across the country in many sectors are sending the same message: jobs exist, skills don’t. In response to this signal, in 2014 Congress passed the bipartisan Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA) to fund and update workforce training programs across the country connects American workers with the skills they need to succeed. This was the first update to America’s job training programs since 1998. Yesterday, one of my committees, the House Education & Workforce Committee conducted a hearing to get input on implementation of the 2014 WIOA. One of the witnesses, Ronald Painter, CEO of the National Association of Workforce Boards, highlighted the Eastern Connecticut Workforce Investment Board and its federally funded ‘manufacturing pipeline’ as an example of one of the most successful training programs in the country. He described how in the last year, EWIB’s metal trades program connected more than 400 people with new jobs in Eastern Connecticut, and there are new classes underway to keep up with more openings. Funding for EWIB comes jointly from the U.S. Dept of Labor and employers, such as Electric Boat.  It was great to see our region touted before the entire Congress, but the hearing also came with a caveat: President Trump's 2018 White House budget seeks to cut job training funds by a staggering 40%. If such a cut happened, the very programs that will open the door to good jobs in the manufacturing and health care fields, to name just a few examples, would as the witnesses testified have to reduce the number of training slots dramatically. This is the opposite of what America’s middle-class needs, and I will work with all my colleagues on both sides of the aisle, to block such a harmful, self-inflicted wound to our nation’s economy.

This morning I joined the ribbon-cutting of a new First Choice Health Center in the Rockville section of Vernon. The brand new facility will perform over 5,000 behavioral health and primary care visits this year alone. Similar community health centers across eastern Connecticut built by First Choice Health Center, United Community Family Center in Norwich, Generations Family Health in Willimantic, and Community Health Centers, Inc. have been made possible by federal funding provided by Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act.   As the Republican-led Senate continues to debate their healthcare bill in total secrecy behind closed doors, we need to remember that the stakes for eastern Connecticut families and millions of other Americans across the country are real. The effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act should not be taken lightly. I believe that this is a gut-check moment for our country and one that will have undeniable consequences for our region for many years to come. I stand willing to work with any of my Republican colleagues who present a real plan to improve our nation’s healthcare system, but I strongly oppose any attempts to cripple or undermine the healthcare delivery system that is working for local families right now.

Our military commanders have said it loud and clear that the U.S. must focus on increasing our undersea warfare capabilities to deal with changing dynamics around the world. To meet that demand, the Seapower Subcommittee, of which I am the ranking member, authorized an increase in the construction rate of Virginia-class submarines at Electric Boat from 2 to 3 per year in the next block contract starting in 2019.    This is outstanding news for the Navy and our region. The increase in work at Electric Boat and the network of nearly 500 parts suppliers across the state forms the backbone of eastern Connecticut’s reinvigorated manufacturing sector, and thanks to the increased submarine production it shows no signs of slowing down. A state-of-the-art submarine force is vital to America’s interests on the world stage and supports jobs and a growing economy right here in our own backyard.

Now that the secret healthcare bill is public with days left before a planned vote, the American people remain firmly opposed to the GOP plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act.  A brand new NBC/Wall Street Journal poll released this morning shows that only 16% of respondents think that the Republican bill is a ‘good idea.’   Seven years ago when Democrats passed the Affordable Care Act, we went through a two-year process with hundreds of committee meetings, exhaustive markups that I personally participated in, and endless hours of floor debate. Only one thing is clear about the new Senate bill: Republicans DO NOT want you to know what is in it, or how it will radically change the protections for American families that were created under the ACA.

The Senate GOP’s healthcare bill has been public for about two days, and already patient groups and health care stakeholders who were shut out of the process are reviewing and responding to the measure. The American Cancer Society Action Network has said: “Patients Would Pay More For Less Coverage Under Senate Health Bill.” And the American Hospital Association: “We Urge The Senate To Go Back To The Drawing Board And Develop Legislation That Continues To Provide Coverage To All Americans Who Currently Have It.”  The effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act should not be taken lightly by anyone – including members of Congress and the public. I believe that this is a gut-check moment for our country and one that will have undeniable consequences for our region for many years to come. I stand with the many healthcare professionals and organizations calling for a more thoughtful approach to improving healthcare for all Americans.

Today’s announcement by Mitch McConnell canceling his rushed vote on the GOP health plan is good news for America’s patients and families. This sudden turnabout did not happen in a vacuum. It was because of the unprecedented outpouring of opposition from groups as diverse and respected as the American Medical Association, American Hospital Association, American Cancer Society, March of Dimes, Catholic Health Association, AARP, Alliance for Retired Americans, Children's Hospital Association, and countless other advocacy groups warning that this bill, written in secret without any care, would harm millions of Americans.  It would damage the infrastructure of our nation’s delivery of services, and hurt nursing homes, rural hospitals, community clinics and elder care. Hopefully after the July 4th recess the Republican majority will heed this call for a responsible public process that will produce bipartisan solutions to fixing our healthcare system.

Yesterday I was pleased to announce that the Connecticut Sea Grant program at the UConn Avery Point campus received a substantial federal grant to aid in research, outreach, and education. Sea Grant is a vital part of our region's maritime economy: it supports our local fishermen, shellfish farmers, and conservation efforts in Long Island Sound. With more than 90 percent of the seafood consumed in the U.S. being imported from foreign countries, the federal Sea Grant program has succeeded in jump-starting Connecticut fisheries in Groton and Norwalk.  This funding underscores how important it is to preserve the Sea Grant program both in Connecticut and across the country. At a national level, Sea Grant has helped to create and sustain 20,770 jobs and almost 3,000 businesses. Unfortunately the 2018 budget threatens to cut funding to Sea Grant. I am leading a group of over 90 of my colleagues to urge continued support for the program.  The proposed elimination of Sea Grant is a counterproductive, anti-growth measure that I will work to reverse.

It was a busy week for the House Armed Services Committee. We worked into early Thursday morning to pass amendments to this year’s National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA), which funds the Department of Defense for the next fiscal year. This year’s NDAA has some great news for our region. It puts us on the path to the 66-ship submarine force that the Navy needs to operate on the global stage, and looks to see even more submarines produced in eastern Connecticut.   The possibility of three subs being built at EB in 2020, 2022, and 2023 would mean an even greater surge in the workforce at Electric Boat, and more economic development around the shipyard and the parts suppliers throughout the state that compose the EB supply chain. I am proud to continue being an advocate for the larger submarine force that our Navy needs and the positive impact their construction has on our region.

Make no mistake- the Senate’s Obamacare repeal bill would be bad news for Connecticut:   -Premiums would be 75% higher under this bill than they would under the ACA. -324,000 more nutmeggers would be uninsured, an increase of 186%. -Our state would lose $2.2 billion of Medicaid and ACA funding.   I have always stood ready to work on a bipartisan basis to pass thoughtful, fact-based solutions to our nation’s healthcare problems. This bill just doesn’t make the cut.

I was glad to see the Washington Examiner recognize the work of myself and some of my Democratic colleagues on the Armed Services Committee to put forward a foreign policy agenda for America’s future. It is imperative that the Democratic Party take the lead on ideas, not just rhetoric aimed at the White House. Our country must be prepared to combat the growing wave of authoritarianism spreading from a Putin-led Russia. Rep. Adam Smith, Seth Moulton, U.S. Congresswoman Stephanie Murphy, Rep. Ruben Gallego, and I put forward our vision for a global strategy for national security in the face of this threat. I hope to continue working closely with them and other forward-thinking members of our party on tangible solutions for our country’s problems home and abroad.

I hope everyone in eastern Connecticut had a wonderful 4th of July. I enjoyed seeing many of you at the famous Willimantic “Boombox Parade.” For those of you who don’t know the story, the town of Willimantic couldn’t find a marching band for their Independence Day parade in 1986, so local residents all carried boomboxes tuned into the local radio station, which provided patriotic music to march along to. It’s a great local tradition that is still going strong. Let me know how you celebrated our country’s independence!

During the last week, I toured the Summer Meals Programs in Groton and Enfield. These programs, funded by the US Department of Agriculture and staffed by AmeriCorps volunteers, provide free meals to children in low-income areas when school is not in session. They also offer educational enrichment and nutrition demonstrations for parents and guardians. There is a real need for these programs in our region and across the country: families in need can save hundreds of dollars per month on food. Unfortunately, the White House’s budget proposal seeks to eliminate AmeriCorps and cut the Department of Agriculture by 20 percent. I will fight to protect these federal programs that make a real difference in our eastern Connecticut communities.

One of my favorite parts of my job is helping veterans get their awarded medals that they never received. Earlier this week, I was honored to present medals to the families of two deceased veterans in Enfield: PFC William A. Gamache, a veteran of the European Theater of WWII who received eight awards including the Bronze Star and Good Conduct medals, and Corporal Gerard Gonyea who received the Korean Ambassador for Peace Medal due to his service in the Korean War.  It was a pleasure to meet the families of these brave men. If you or a veteran you know needs help getting their medals, please contact Manny Menses at my Norwich office: 860-886-0139.

The continued ramp-up in work at Electric Boat and parts manufacturers across the state means more job openings in eastern Connecticut, which is always welcome news. But our region would be best served if these jobs were filled by local residents. Schools like Asnuntuck Community College in Enfield are crucial parts of this effort, and this week I was pleased to tour their brand new Advanced Manufacturing Center that opened late last month.   The 27,000 square foot, $25 million facility will enable the college to potentially double both its current full-time enrollment of 250-300 manufacturing students and 500-1,000 students in its incumbent worker program. This is exactly the kind of local, state, and federal collaboration that our region needs as we continue our economic recovery.

I recently spoke with the Connecticut Mirror about the urgent need to increase the Coast Guard’s budget in order to keep up with the growing list of demands being placed on the service.  Our region has deep maritime traditions and is the proud home of the U.S. Coast Guard Academy. We know firsthand the critical role the Coast Guard plays in protecting our shores. However, many people are not aware that the Coast Guard is being asked to fill an ever-expanding role in protecting our national security far from the U.S. mainland.   Whether it is intercepting drug traffickers abroad, guarding critical infrastructure from terrorist threats, or conducting accident investigations like the recent collision of the USS Fitzgerald, the Coast Guard plays a key role in protecting our national interests on a global level and they need a budget that reflects their mission. The Coast Guard has been asked to do more with less for far too long. I am now leading the fight in Congress to increase funding in order to make sure our Guard members have the tools and the training they need. Semper Peratus!

Yesterday I headed to Fort Trumbull for the Change of Command and Retirement Ceremony for Captain Dennis Evans, the head of the Coast Guard’s Research and Development Center in New London. Captain Evans wrapped up a long and decorated career of 24 years in the Coast Guard, supervising projects as diverse as the Offshore Petrol Cutter, Polar Icebreaker Program, and the FireScout Unmanned Aerial Vehicle. He gave a touching tribute to his family, who have followed his career across the country, never staying in one place for more than three years. Now that he is retired, they’ll be making their long-term home here in eastern Connecticut, a place they can finally point to as “home.” Thank you, Captain Evans, for your service to our great nation.

Some welcome news: The Afghanistan girls' robotics team is now being allowed to come to the United States for their competition. This is exactly what my colleagues and I were looking for when I led a letter to Secretary Tillerson on this matter earlier this week. I am glad that the Trump Administration has reversed their decision and that these girls will be allowed to compete.

Today, the House passed the 2018 National Defense Authorization Act by a wide bipartisan margin. The bill makes it the policy of our nation to achieve a 355-ship Navy and authorizes the building of 3 Virginia-class submarines per year to support that goal. I have been a strong proponent of increasing submarine production to meet growing threats around the globe since my earliest days in Congress. When I took office, our nation was only producing 1 attack submarine per year, and we had not built a ballistic missile submarine since the 1980’s.   Electric Boat will soon begin production on the first new ballistic missile sub in three decades and could be building 3 attack submarines per year under the next submarine contract. IMPORTANT READ: A comprehensive timeline of recent developments at the federal level to address the ongoing crisis of crumbling foundations by the Journal Inquirer. The Commissioner of the IRS and the National Taxpayer Advocate who works within the IRS have stated that they support federal tax relief for homeowners harmed by crumbling foundations. This was a result of a joint effort between my office and Rep. John Larson's office to engage with the IRS and the Secretary of the Treasury over the last few months. We still have a lot of work to do, but having key federal officials publicly acknowledge the merits of casualty loss tax assistance for local homeowners is an encouraging development.

I am very pleased that the House Appropriations Committee heeded the bipartisan effort I led with Rep. Zeldin (R-NY) to protect federal funding for the National Sea Grant College program. Sea Grant programs in Connecticut are a vital part of our region’s maritime economy. Based out of UConn’s Avery Point campus, scientists collaborate with local fishermen, shellfish farmers, and environmentalists to keep our waters vibrant for marine fisheries and other aquatic activities.  Unfortunately, the Trump Budget proposed to eliminate all funding for this critical program and the jobs it supports. Congressman Zeldin and I led nearly 100 of our colleagues in a bipartisan effort urging the Appropriations Committee to reject those cuts and keep Sea Grant fully funded. I am glad that they recognized the importance of this national program, and have passed a budget that maintains that funding.

The headline says it all. After obstructionists promised instant repeal of the Affordable Care Act for the last eight years, the real life harm such a feckless promise would cause to 20 million Americans finally sunk in and repeal died on the Senate floor. As hospitals, doctors, nurses, patient groups such as the American Cancer Society, March of Dimes, and many other real life stakeholders pointed out, the ACA made dozens of important changes to our healthcare system, including prohibiting pre-existing condition exclusions once and for all. However, like Medicare, which has been modified over 50 times, the ACA needs improvements that both parties can fix.   In order to make those fixes, President Trump and his allies need to recognize the progress the ACA made for 20 million Americans who had no insurance and build on that progress. That's what real life healthcare groups- outside of the Washington DC and cable news bubble- are saying, and it's time for the White House and Congressional leaders to listen.

I headed over to the FIRST global competition to meet the Afghanistan girls’ robotics team. They were initially barred by the State Department from traveling to the United States, but after reading their story, I led 53 of my colleagues in sending a letter to Secretary Tillerson urging him to let the girls compete.  I’m very glad that the Trump Administration reversed course on this decision. I was impressed with the poise and dedication of these girls, and look forward to their bright futures. Many of them hope to attend college in the United States. I hope we can welcome them with open arms when that time comes.

It’s six months into the new administration, and Betsy DeVos still has not testified before the House Education & Workforce committee. Teachers, administrators, and parents in eastern Connecticut have pressing questions about how the Every Student Succeeds Act- which replaced No Child Left Behind- should be implemented. But the Department of Education continues to send mixed messages. As Secretary, it is her responsibility to be accountable for the confusion that exists in school districts all across the country. Her absence at the House Education Committee is unprecedented. Prior secretaries from Republican and Democratic administrations have always made themselves available to explain their budgets and policies. I can attest that her absence is unacceptable to members on both sides of the aisle in the House.

Last February, President Trump met with CEOs from America’s largest manufacturers. They made their message loud and clear: Jobs exist, skills don’t. Yesterday, Republicans rejected that message and cut all funding to apprenticeship grants in their partisan budget. This is a tone-deaf move. We should listen to job creators and CEOs, reject this budget, and invest in job training to close the skills gap.

Late this week, I hosted an event with Electric Boat, small businesses, and workers to express dismay over a partisan budget passed in committee that strips federal support for apprenticeship programs. Back in February, America's manufacturing employers told the White House that in order to fix the economy we need to fix the skills gap. A newspaper headline the following morning said it in a nutshell: ‘jobs exist; skills don’t’. The GOP budget passed out of committee last Wednesday willfully ignores that message by butchering job training programs that have a proven track record of success. I was very pleased last week when members from both sides of the aisle came together to pass a historic update to the G.I. bill that will benefit generations of service members in the years ahead. The House passed the Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act of 2017, a significant improvement to the Post-9/11 G.I. Bill that will extend educational benefits to all qualified veterans and service members who were in active duty as of January 1, 2013. For those qualifying veterans, this will mean that their educational benefits will be available to them for the rest of their life. Additionally, it ensures these benefits are granted to future veterans, their surviving spouses and dependents, as well as recipients of the Purple Heart.   Eastern Connecticut is the proud home to more veterans than any other congressional district in the state. In 2010, I was a cosponsor of the Post-9/11 G.I. Bill - the most important update to the benefit since the end of World War II - that boosted the amount of tuition assistance and for the first time allowed the benefit to be transferred to service members’ spouses and dependents. Now, this new bill will ensure that G.I. Bill benefits will be available throughout the lifetime of all veterans who enlisted after 2013. This bill also closed an egregious loophole: it ensures fairness for Connecticut National Guard members who have deployed overseas that were previously not eligible for G.I. Bill benefits.

A major ongoing effort I have been fighting for in Congress is getting care for Blue Water Navy veterans of the Vietnam War who were exposed to Agent Orange. Today, I continued that fight by joining one of my Republican colleagues, Rep. David Valadao in sending a letter to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to ask that he provide us with information on the Department’s review of Agent Orange exposure coverage for Blue Water Navy vets.  During the war, nearly 20 million gallons of the Agent Orange herbicide were used to clear vegetation as part of “Operation Ranch Hand” from 1961 to 1971. Blue Water Navy ships operated in the waters surrounding Vietnam, and sailors were unknowingly exposed to water that was contaminated with the chemical. Thus, some 90,000 Navy sailors were likely exposed to this toxic chemical used during the war even if they did not set foot on land. But for the past 15 years, the VA has refused to provide coverage for Blue Water vets. Rep. Valadao and I are hoping that the current review being conducted at VA will change that, and we will continue to pursue the VA to get more information until this is done.

Groton is well-known as the “submarine capital of the world,” but you may not know that our region is the birthplace of submersible combat. If you’ve visited the Submarine Force Museum in Groton, you’ve seen a replica of the Turtle submersible on display. Turtle was the world’s first submersible to be used in battle. It was designed and constructed by David Bushnell from Saybrook, Connecticut. Its propeller was powered by foot-pedals and it had a hand-powered drill that was meant to attach time-bombs to the bottom of British ships. Turtle was deployed in New York Harbor in 1776, piloted by Ezra Lee from Lyme, Connecticut, but never managed to penetrate the hull of the British flagship.   The story of Turtle was recently featured in the Naval History and Heritage Command publication, along with several original documents about the vessel’s construction, and letters between George Washington and Thomas Jefferson discussing its potential. The page also highlights the construction of a replica constructed students from Old Saybrook High School. Check it out below!

Yesterday, Rep. John Larson and I had a productive meeting with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to discuss the ongoing crisis of homeowners with crumbling foundations in north-central Connecticut. This meeting stemmed from a request Rep. Larson and I made for a meeting earlier this year, as well as the support we have received from the National Taxpayer Advocate. Specifically, we wanted to discuss an IRS “revenue procedure”, or a guidance document that, if approved would allow homeowners to deduct foundation repair costs from their federal taxes. The Treasury Department’s Office of Tax Policy directs the issuance of these documents, which are then prepared by the IRS. After meeting with the secretary and his staff, it is clear that they are engaged on this issue and understand the urgent situation facing residents in Connecticut. His office indicated that they would continue to evaluate the situation before making a final determination.   As we have said all along, there is not going to be one silver bullet that solves the entire problem of crumbling foundations for homeowners. Instead, we need a concerted effort at the municipal, state, and federal levels and this could be an important and valuable piece of the puzzle. We still have a lot of work to do, but having a key federal official publicly acknowledge the merits of casualty loss tax assistance for local homeowners is an encouraging development.

CONNECTICUT DREAMER: I recently met with a local graduate, Shaquille Jessop, in my Enfield district office. Shaquille is one of many young people in Connecticut and across the country known as DREAMers, meaning that they were brought to the United States as young children and have grown-up as Americans. Shaquille was brought to the U.S. from Barbados when he was just 5 years old. When the 2-year visas that brought his family to the U.S. expired, his parents made the decision to overstay and since then Shaquille has spent his entire life in Connecticut going to school and graduating from Enfield High School.   After high school, Shaquille then went on to Asnuntuck Community College and graduated in 2016 becoming an assistant manager at a local business, supporting himself and paying taxes. While he obtained temporary legal status under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program known as DACA, he is now set to lose that reprieve after President Trump decided to rescind DACA last week.   As Shaquille’s story shows, the president’s order will punish children who have grown up in this country for the actions of their parents. Not only is this fundamentally unfair, it will lead to the indiscriminate deportation of some of the brightest and most talented young people in our country. It is because of stories like Shaquille that I am a cosponsor of the DREAM Act that will codify DACA and allow him and others like him to contribute to American society. HELP FOR PUERTO RICO. With every passing hour, we learn more about the true scope of the crisis unfolding in Puerto Rico. Much of the island remains without power or communications, and in many areas supplies are running low. I am grateful to see the Navy and Marine Corps on the front lines of response to the devastation. Right now, the crews of the USS Kearsarge (LHD-3), USS Wasp (LHD-1) and USS Oak Hill (LSD-51) are working to clear airfields and provide relief to their fellow Americans on the island. The Coast Guard is also responding, with several ships on the scene. And, earlier today, a portion of the 103rd Airlift Wing of the Connecticut Air National Guard departed for Puerto Rico to help re-establish communications capabilities.   Even with these efforts, however, it is clear that federal agencies need to speed up response efforts and deploy increased military and civilian resources. Congress must also act quickly to make sure that Puerto Rico, and other areas of our country hit hard by hurricanes, have the urgent support and resources they need. This must be a priority from the top down.

Yesterday, I joined 150 colleagues in urging Defense Secretary James Mattis to deploy additional military assets to support the response to the crisis in Puerto Rico. In our letter, we underscored the urgent need for getting food and water to the people of Puerto Rico, help to restore access to power and clean water.   I am pleased that last night I received word from the Navy that the USNS COMFORT, one of our nation's two hospital ships, is preparing to travel to the island. And, today, the Pentagon assigned one-star Army General to oversee response and recovery efforts.   These are good additions to the response, and I will continue to do all I can to get Puerto Rico the help and support they need in this difficult time.

LAS VEGAS: Our nation reached a sickening milestone last night as the attack in Las Vegas became our worst mass shooting event on record. I mourn with the families of those killed and injured as they join the growing group of Americans who stand to witness to this great and largely preventable scourge of violence. In the days ahead, we will learn more about the victims and survivors, the shooter and his motives.   It is our responsibility as a nation to go beyond mourning these losses. Time after time, we have stood in moments of silence and offered our thoughts and prayers, then swiftly moved on, leaving behind shattered families and no change. There are specific steps that Congress should take right now - enacting comprehensive background check legislation, properly funding research into the effects of gun violence and ways to prevent it, and fully implementing the laws we already have on the books.   We may not be able to prevent all future injuries, but we owe it to all those lost and injured in so many communities – such as Sandy Hook, Orlando, the Navy Yard, Tucson, San Bernardino, Fort Hood, Oregon, Colorado, Wisconsin, Alexandria, Charleston, and now Las Vegas – to try.

I recently joined school officials in celebrating a new five-year, $15 million federal grant to invest in high-quality magnet schools in our region. The grant, which was the result of months of hard work by the team at the LEARN Coalition, supports the establishment of four intradistrict magnet schools in Groton and Norwich and significant curriculum revision at existing LEARN interdistrict magnet schools in New London.   As I noted at our event on Friday, magnet schools break down social barriers and provide Connecticut families with the ability to choose programs that most appeal to their children’s academic talents and interests, in a system that is publicly accountable to the taxpayer.  As our state’s towns and schools face uncertainty in funding their educational needs this year, this federal funding award provides some measure of stability for the future of these great public schools.  I am proud to have worked with the team at LEARN to advocate for this grant and will continue to fight in Washington for investment in our region and nation’s magnet schools.

Agriculture is part of the tapestry of eastern Connecticut, and a key part of our region’s and state’s economy. As Congress continues to look at updates to the Farm Bill and other federal agriculture policies, I will continue to work across the aisle to support these sectors and the new growth in Connecticut agriculture we are seeing today.

The United States and Australia have a strong enduring relationship - one that was forged on the battlefields of WWI.  This year marks the 100th anniversary of our friendship, trust, and mutual respect - in a word, our “mateship”.  In honor of our past and commitment to our future, I joined Congressman Mike Gallagher (R-WI) in launching the bipartisan Congressional Friends of Australia Caucus.   Australia and the U.S. are strategic partners in defense, trade, and other global issues.  The Friends of Australia Caucus, currently comprised of 44 bipartisan members, is meant to foster open dialogue between Members of Congress and our Australian allies.  This week we formally launched the Caucus with the Australian Embassy (Australia in the United States). The Australian Embassy is celebrating our 100 years of “mateship” to highlight the close ties we’ve formed fighting side by side in every major conflict over the last century.  I look forward to working with my “mates” both in the Congress and in Australia on continuing to strengthen the relationship between our two great countries.

UNDERMINING OUR INSURANCE MARKETS -- This morning, President Trump took another major step towards the destabilization and sabotage of our health insurance system, signing an Executive Order undermining the historic consumer protections included in the ACA. The order allows for the unfettered growth of “Association Health Plans” and exempts them from covering Essential Health Benefits such as maternity care or mental health care, leaving those patients unprotected and vulnerable.   This is not a new idea –  in the 1990s these plans existed and failed to protect thousands of patients from financial risk when they needed it most. These plans have generated heated opposition from experts, state insurance commissioners and others who know that ducking consumer protections is dangerous for patients.   Earlier this year I spoke about Association Health Plans on the House floor to explain this approach really enables a “race to the bottom”. Allowing insurance companies to decide what benefits are essential and letting them skirt rules that ensure that they have the funds to pay the bills is unsafe and irresponsible. This order is a monumental step backward from the goal of expanding quality and affordable coverage, and undermines the stability of our insurance market at a time when we should be discussing bipartisan ways to stabilize the market and thoughtfully build on the Affordable Care Act.

As I mentioned in my remarks, the christening of the 17th Virginia class submarine has special meaning for our region because she was built here during the renaissance-era of growth and innovation.   As those of us in Connecticut know, the Groton shipyard looks dramatically different than it did nine years ago when South Dakota was first authorized by Congress. Congratulations to the talented shipbuilders in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Virginia that have made this submarine a reality. It is a tangible example of how far we have come – and the opportunities still ahead of us.

The House is preparing to vote on a budget that will fast-track a process to change our tax system. While I have long agreed that we need to overhaul our tax system that better serves our economy and our middle class, the approach outlined in this budget resolution marches in the opposite direction.   Specifically, the budget we will vote on tomorrow directly calls for the repeal of the state and local tax deduction. This deduction is not some tax break merely for millionaires, as some would have you think – 41% of Connecticut tax returns claimed this deduction on their tax returns in 2015, ensuring that these taxpayers did not have to pay federal taxes on income paid as taxes to the state or to their towns. Yes, high-income residents of our state and other higher tax states claim this deduction. But so do 23.2% of Connecticut taxpayers with income between $25,000 and $50,000, and more than 48% of taxpayers with income between $50,000 and $75,000 - hardly millionaires.   I’m ready to work on a tax plan that boosts the middle class and ensures fairness in our tax system. The plan outlined in the budget this week, however, falls far short of those goals.

For nearly two years, I have called for a National Public Health Emergency -- coupled with robust funding and resources -- to be declared to combat the opioid crisis. I welcome President Trump’s declaration of a public health emergency yesterday as a step towards recognizing the severity of the crisis.   This declaration, however, falls short of the tangible steps I believe are needed to combat the opioid crisis. Across eastern Connecticut, what I have heard is that those responding on the front lines need more funding to expand treatment bed availability, access to life-saving Narcan, and intervention efforts to prevent opioid addiction. Yesterday’s action, however, unlocks no new resources to address these and puts no new funding in the Public Health Emergency Fund that is unlocked by the declaration - that fund has only about $57,000 in it today.   I hope that President Trump’s declaration is a start, not an end, to his administration's efforts to tackle the opioid crisis. I stand ready to work with him, and my colleagues on both sides of the aisle in Congress, to provide the funding, support, and resources needed in eastern Connecticut communities and those across our nation grappling with this problem every day.

NEW TAX PLAN - While I’m still going through the tax plan released today by House Speaker Paul Ryan, I am deeply concerned about what I have seen so far. While the plan on its face would lower taxes for some, it eliminates specific provisions that families in eastern Connecticut rely on. For instance, the proposed tax plan would eliminate the deduction for state and local income and sales taxes - a repeal that would disproportionately affect taxpayers in higher cost states like Connecticut. It also repeals the deduction of student loan interest and and college expenses, and eliminates the newly expanded family credit - a worthy effort - after five years.   This bill is simultaneously packed with giveaways to the wealthiest taxpayers and largest corporations. The bill eliminates the estate tax, a tax that affects only the wealthiest Americans and less than 1% of taxpayers. This provision alone will increase the national deficit by an estimated $172 billion.  Instead of working across the aisle on a thoughtful and bipartisan approach to simplifying and improving our tax system, House Republicans are rushing to move this plan -- released only hours ago -- through the legislative process as fast as possible. Every single American is impacted by the changes that will be made by this measure, and deserves an open and transparent process. I’ll continue to work on a plan that boosts our middle class and supports eastern Connecticut taxpayers. NAVY SHIP COLLISIONS REPORT - Yesterday, the Navy released the findings from its investigations into the string of ship collisions that occurred this summer and over the last year. The review does not sugar coat the fact that glaring deficiencies in training and leadership subjected our Sailors and ships assigned to the Western Pacific region to unacceptable risks. With increasing operational tempos in the region, the forward-deployed ships based in Japan -- which included both the USS McCain and USS Fitzgerald -- largely operated outside of the regular guidelines and “fire breaks” that monitor crew readiness and ship conditions. As a result, and as these reports outline in a sobering and heartbreaking manner, ships and their crews were deploying regularly without the certifications and training they needed - and without the leadership structure to call “time out.”  The Navy’s review outlines a list of 58 recommendations aimed at getting to the root of these problems. However, there are a few that I believe the Navy should focus on and implement without delay - such as establishing a single headquarters command that is solely responsible for the manning, training and equipping of Navy forces in the Western Pacific.  As Ranking Member of the House Seapower and Projection Forces subcommittee, I am committed to ensuring that Congress will be an active partner in ensuring that the recommendations are acted on and that the Navy has the resources and support it needs to get it done.   This cannot be a moment that passes without action and follow-through. It has to be the start of real and tangible change. Our Sailors, their families, and the nation that relies on them to preserve our security at home and around the world should expect nothing less.  http://www.theday.com/military-news/20171102/navy-review-finds-gaps-in-training-basic-seamanship-in-western-pacific

OPIOIDS IN NEW ENGLAND: Earlier this week, I joined my colleagues from other New England states to receive a briefing from regional Drug Enforcement Administration officials about the work law enforcement is doing in our region to prevent heroin and fentanyl from reaching our neighborhoods. Their taskforce approach brings together local, state, and federal law enforcement to coordinate all efforts to get these dangerous drugs off the streets in our state.  Alarmingly, they reported that three people die from an overdose every day and that Fentanyl-related deaths in Connecticut increased by a shocking 544% between 2014 and 2016. Encouragingly, the DEA reported that the long upward trend in overdose deaths could be slowing, a sign that getting Naloxone into the hands of first responders is working. However, not all towns have the financial resources to arm their officers with this life-saving drug, a financial barrier that results in preventable loss of life and untold tragedy.    These DEA officials agree that in order to really make headway towards ending this crisis, we need to approach both the supply of drugs entering the community and provide lifesaving emergency care and long-term recovery to those struggling with addiction. This starts with funding what we know works. In Congress, I have prioritized providing emergency funding to local law enforcement so that we can make sure Naloxone is available when it’s needed most, and I will keep working hard to get this done.

Last week, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) voted to repeal the 2015 Open Internet Order which put in place net neutrality rules on internet service providers This included the big four principles of an open internet: transparency, no blocking, no throttling, and no paid prioritization. I strongly opposed this move and urged the FCC to delay its vote.  Now that the FCC has acted, however, I believe that Congress must do its part to protect an open internet. That is why I have signed on to a measure being written by my colleague Congressman Mike Doyle (D-MA) to reverse this policy through the Congressional Review Act (CRA). While this resolution cannot be formally introduced until the final FCC policy is published in the federal register, which may not occur for several weeks or months, I signed on as an early supporter of this effort to make absolutely clear where I stand on this important issue.

Earlier this month, Navy Secretary Richard Spencer released the results of his “strategic review” looking at the causes of the Navy ship collisions in the Pacific and reforms needed to avoid them in the future. The review makes serious recommendations on how the Navy should train, man, equip, organize, and command the surface force around the world.  Some reforms have already been implemented by the Navy using its existing authorities. Other changes will require action on the part of Congress. For example, for many years legislative language in the annual defense funding bill has mandated a split between the Pacific and Atlantic fleets of our surface forces, which as the new review points out has led to confusion in responsibilities and lack of consistent standards across the fleet.  I believe the Secretary’s review makes a strong case to Congress for the need to rethink this policy. I discussed the need for Congressional action with Breaking Defense recently. The completion of these reviews marks the beginning of a process for both the Navy and Congress to implement and oversee reforms needed to address the shortfalls exposed by the collisions. We owe it to the families of our lost sailors and to the families who entrust us to give their sailors the training and resources they need to do their job safely and effectively. As ranking member of the Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittee, this will be a top priority for me when Congress returns next year.
